newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: RTRS-AMLC Beef Weekly - Australian export prices.
newsitem.headline: RTRS-AMLC Beef Weekly - Australian export prices.

text.p: Australian Meat and Livestock Corp's (AMLC) weekly export prices are as follows:
AUSTRALIAN EXPORT PRICES TO U.S. IN U.S. CENTS/LB, CIF.
Bull (95 Chemical Lean) 93 -1 on last week
AUSTRALIAN EXPORT PRICES TO JAPAN IN U.S. CENTS/LB CIF.
Chilled grassfed fullsets 119 +3 on last week
AMLC COMMENTARY: Values in most cattle markets this week showed only slight variations with no strong trends evident.
Bullock markets were firm across Australia, despite the recent E. Coli issue in Japan. The E. Coli issue remained the dominant influence opun export demand for Australian beef.
Sales of perishable foodstuffs at supermarkets in Japan in July declined 3.1 percent from year-ago levels and analysts are pessimistic about sales in August.

Beef exports from the U.S. to Japan are down by 30 percent because of the E. Coli related epidemic. Australian beef exports have likewise suffered. Beef exports to Japan for August will probably be about 20,000 tonnes compared with 29,000 tonnes in August 1995.
There were further signs this week that the impact of E. Coli may be starting to abate. Export prices for chilled grassfed fullsets increased slightly by 3 US cents/lb or by 7 Ac/kg.

Slow trade to Japan and industrial problems caused several works in Australia to close. Adult cattle slaughter in Queensland last week was 46,209 head, 24 percent below the same week last year. In New South Wales, slaughter was 34,545 head, down seven percent.
Still, store cattle sales in Australia this week showed some signs of confidence.

In, the U.S., beef markets were generally quiet and prices lower this week with the trade on hold until after the Labor Day holiday. General expectations that cow slaughter will be heavy in the U.S. autumn gave the market a slightly bearish tone.
Australian grinding beef prices were generally lower this week.
